title: Simulate a population using the dynamic pool model
text: simyears minLL require single numeric value. example simulates population 50 years minimum length limit 400mm. lhparms requires list vector created makeLH() function. makeLH() function creates list life history parameters needed. Including, initial number recruits, maximum age fish population, von Bertalanffy growth model parameters (L∞L_\infty, KK, t0t_0), parameters log10-transformed weight length model (alpha beta). default, makeLH() returns list. Growth length-weight model paramaters can generated functions FSA package. See [Make Life History object article(MakeLH.html)] details. example uses following life history parameters: cf cm matrix rows = simyears (number years specified simulation) columns = tmax (maximum age). example assigns cm 0 first year 0.18 remaining years constant across ages; cf 0 first year 0.33 remaining years constant across ages. Note, Ages must age-0 maximum age. Thus, cf cm matrix maximum age plus one rows. Recruitment must vector length simyears contain single value year. Users can specify vector manually use genRecruits() function allows user specify different trends recruitment. example sets recruitment fixed 1000 individuals year.
code: simyears <- 50 minLL <- 400 # create life history parameter object LH <- makeLH(N0=100,tmax=15,Linf=1349.5,K=0.111,t0=0.065,LWalpha=-5.2147,LWbeta=3.153) cm <- matrix(rep(c(rep(0,1), rep(0.18,(LH$tmax))), simyears),nrow=simyears,byrow=TRUE) cf <- matrix(rep(c(rep(0,1), rep(0.33,(LH$tmax))), simyears),nrow=simyears,byrow=TRUE) rec <- genRecruits(method = "fixed", nR = 1000, simyears = simyears)

title: Simulate a population using the dynamic pool model
text: output contains lot information several potential figures can constructed. examples figures might interest. first set figures explore data summarized age second set figures explore data summarized year. First, custom theme created use across plots. three figures plot 1) yield vs age single year class 2) harvest vs age 3) biomass vs age. Note since recruitment, cf, cm fixed across year classes, year classes age vs total yield.    next set figures explore output summary year. first figure PSD vs year second figure Yield age 1 plus vs year. Note figure reaches asymtote age classes present population. recruitment, cm, cf held constant across years.
code: # Custom theme for plots (to make look nice) theme_FAMS <- function(...) {  theme_bw() +  theme(    panel.grid.major=element_blank(),panel.grid.minor=element_blank(),    axis.text=element_text(size=14,color="black"),    axis.title=element_text(size=16,color="black"),    axis.title.y=element_text(angle=90),    axis.line=element_line(color="black"),    panel.border=element_blank()  ) } #Plot date using summary by age for a specific year class #filter for year class = 40 plotdat<- out1[[1]] |> filter(yc==40)  #Plot yield vs age ggplot(data=plotdat,mapping=aes(x=age,y=yield)) +   geom_point() +   geom_line() +   labs(y="Total yield (g)",x="Age") +   theme_FAMS() #Plot Number harvested vs age ggplot(data=plotdat,mapping=aes(x=age,y=nharvest)) +   geom_point() +   geom_line() +   labs(y="Number harvested",x="Age") +   theme_FAMS() #Plot Number biomass vs age ggplot(data=plotdat,mapping=aes(x=age,y=biomass)) +   geom_point() +   geom_line() +   labs(y="Biomass (g)",x="Age") +   theme_FAMS() #Use summary by year data frame to plot PSD vs year ggplot(data=out1[[2]],mapping=aes(x=year,y=PSD)) +   geom_point() +   geom_line() +   labs(y="PSD",x="Year") +   theme_FAMS() #Use summary by year data frame to plot yield vs year ggplot(data=out1[[2]],mapping=aes(x=year,y=Yield_age_1plus)) +   geom_point() +   geom_line() +   labs(y="Total yield (g)",x="Year") +   theme_FAMS()

what: Build a life history parameter object from user specified values
title: Create life history object
text: Life history parameters required yield-per-recruit dynamic pool modeling include initial number recruits, maximum age, von Bertalanffy growth model parameters (L∞L_\infty, KK, t0t_0) parameters log10-transformed weight length model (alpha beta). must stored list vector, default makeLH() returns values list. Users option building list manually makeLH() function contains series checks can identify potential errors. list returned values displayed number decimals provided user. vector returned number decimals displayed value match value supplied user decimals. Thus, list preferred easier match given expected given. first example explicitly specifies argument. two created objects (LHparamsList LHparamsVector) can used core rFAMS functions.
code: #Return parameters as a list LHparamsList <- makeLH(N0=100,tmax=15,Linf=500,K=0.3,t0=-0.5,LWalpha=-5.613,LWbeta=3.1) #View life history object LHparamsList #> $N0 #> [1] 100 #>  #> $tmax #> [1] 15 #>  #> $Linf #> [1] 500 #>  #> $K #> [1] 0.3 #>  #> $t0 #> [1] -0.5 #>  #> $LWalpha #> [1] -5.613 #>  #> $LWbeta #> [1] 3.1  #Return parameters as a vector LHparamsVector <- makeLH(N0=100,tmax=15,Linf=500,K=0.3,t0=-0.5,LWalpha=-5.613,LWbeta=3.1,                          restype="vector") #View life history object LHparamsVector #>      N0    tmax    Linf       K      t0 LWalpha  LWbeta  #> 100.000  15.000 500.000   0.300  -0.500  -5.613   3.100

what: Build a life history parameter object from model output
title: Create life history object
text: makeLH() function also allows model objects input von Bertalanffy growth length-weight models. See FSA package information fitting von Bertalanffy growth models length-weight models. model object created passed makeLH() function Linf LWalpha arguments.
code: ## Load data from FSAdata package, restrict to one location and year, ##   create log10 values of weight and length data(WalleyeErie2,package="FSAdata") tmp <- WalleyeErie2 |>   filter(loc==2,year==2010) |>   mutate(logW=log10(w),          logL=log10(tl))  ## Generate LVB results vb1 <- FSA::makeGrowthFun(type="von Bertalanffy") fit1 <- nls(tl~vb1(age,Linf,K,t0),data=tmp,             start=FSA::findGrowthStarts(tl~age,data=tmp))  ## Generate length-weight regression results fit2 <- lm(logW~logL,data=tmp) ## Make life-history list with those results waeLH <- makeLH(N0=100,tmax=20,Linf=fit1,LWalpha=fit2) waeLH #> $N0 #> [1] 100 #>  #> $tmax #> [1] 20 #>  #> $Linf #> [1] 587.9484 #>  #> $K #> [1] 0.4851255 #>  #> $t0 #> [1] -1.050782 #>  #> $LWalpha #> [1] -5.857295 #>  #> $LWbeta #> [1] 3.329038

title: Comparing FAMS and Ricker YPR Equations
text: Beverton-Holt yield-per-recruit (YPR) equation according FAMS documentation : Y=FNteZrW∞K[β(X,P,Q)−β(X1,P,Q)] Y = \frac{FN_{t}e^{Zr}W_{\infty}}{K} [\beta(X,P,Q)-\beta(X1,P,Q)] Beverton-Holt YPR equation according Ricker : Y=FN0eFrW∞K[β(X,P,Q)−β(X1,P,Q)] Y = \frac{FN_{0}e^{Fr}W_{\infty}}{K} [\beta(X,P,Q)-\beta(X1,P,Q)] Note use NtN_t vs N0N_0 use ZZ vs FF (exponent). Parameters defined : FF instantaneous fishing mortality. MM instantaneous natural mortality (). ZZ instantaneous natural mortality. t0t_0 hypothetical age (.e., time) mean length zero. trt_r age (.e., time) fish recruit fishery (.e., reach minimum length example). tλt_\lambda maximum age fish population (). rr time takes recruit fishery (r=tr−t0r=t_r-t_0). N0N_0 number recruits population t0t_0. NtN_t number recruits fishery trt_r (=N0e−MtrN_{0}e^{-Mt_{r}}). W∞W_\infty average asymptotic weight fish. KK Brody growth coefficient von Bertalanffy growth model. bb slope log10(Weight)log_{10}(Weight)-log10(Length)log_{10}(Length) linear model fit (). X=e−KrX=e^{-Kr} X1=e−K(tλ−t0)X1=e^{-K(t_\lambda-t_0)} P=ZKP=\frac{Z}{K} Q=b+1Q=b+1

However, difficult include eMt0e^{Mt_0} term coding include accurate Ricker possible? addition, likely makes sense include term Ricker defines N0N_0 “hypothetical number individuals reach hypothetical age t0t_0 annually” rather initial number recruits age 0. seems reasonable term “handle” natural mortality time t0t_0 0.
code: FAMSvRicker1 <- function(N0,F,M,tr,t0) {   Nt <- N0*exp(-M*tr)   r <- tr-t0   Z <- F+M   data.frame(t0,              FAMS=Nt*exp(Z*r),              RCKR=N0*exp(F*r)) |>     dplyr::mutate(percdiff=100*(FAMS-RCKR)/RCKR) } tmp <- FAMSvRicker1(100,0.2,0.3,1,seq(-2,2,length.out=100))  ggplot(data=tmp,mapping=aes(y=percdiff,x=t0)) +   geom_point() +   geom_hline(yintercept=0,color="red",linetype="dashed") +   geom_vline(xintercept=0,color="red",linetype="dashed") +   labs(x="t_0",y="Percent Difference",title="Yield Portion: FAMS vs Ricker") +   theme_bw() FAMSvRicker <- function(N0,F,M,tr,t0,tlambda,Linf,K,a,b) {   Nt <- N0*exp(-M*tr)   r <- tr-t0   Z <- F+M   Winf <- 10^(a+b*log10(Linf))   P <- Z/K   Q <- b+1   X <- exp(-K*r)   X1 <- exp(-K*(tlambda-t0))   betas <- rFAMS:::iIbeta(X,P,Q)-rFAMS:::iIbeta(X1,P,Q)    data.frame(t0,              FAMS=((F*Nt*exp(Z*r)*Winf)/K)*betas,              cFAMS=((F*Nt*exp(Z*r)*Winf)/K)*betas*exp(M*t0),              RCKR=((F*N0*exp(F*r)*Winf)/K)*betas) |>     dplyr::mutate(percdiff=100*(FAMS-RCKR)/RCKR,                   cpercdiff=100*(cFAMS-RCKR)/RCKR) } tmp <- FAMSvRicker(N0=100,F=0.2,M=0.3,tr=1,t0=seq(-2,1,length.out=100),                    tlambda=10,Linf=500,K=3.1,a=-5.6,b=3.1) ggplot(data=tmp,mapping=aes(y=percdiff,x=t0)) +   geom_point() +   geom_hline(yintercept=0,color="red",linetype="dashed") +   geom_vline(xintercept=0,color="red",linetype="dashed") +   labs(x="t_0",y="Percent Difference",title="Yield: FAMS vs Ricker") +   theme_bw() ggplot(data=tmp,mapping=aes(y=cpercdiff,x=t0)) +   geom_point() +   geom_hline(yintercept=0,color="red",linetype="dashed") +   geom_vline(xintercept=0,color="red",linetype="dashed") +   labs(x="t_0",y="Percent Difference",title="Yield: 'Corrected' FAMS vs Ricker") +   theme_bw()

what: Build a life history parameter list
title: Estimate yield based on a single minimum length limit
text: first step using rFAMS simulation models create object life history parameters using makeLH() function. makeLH() function creates list life history parameters needed. Including, initial number recruits, maximum age fish population, von Bertalanffy growth model parameters (L∞L_\infty, KK, t0t_0), parameters log10-transformed weight length model (alpha beta). default, makeLH() returns list. Growth length-weight model paramaters can generated functions FSA package. example uses following life history parameters: initial number recruits, set 100. tmax maximum age population years, set 15. Linf point estimate asymptotic mean length von Bertalanffy growth model, set 592mm. K (upper case) point estimate Brody growth coefficient von Bertalanffy growth model, set 0.20. t0 point estimate x-intercept (.e., theoretical age mean length 0) von Bertalanffy growth model, set -0.3. LWalpha point estimate alpha length-weight regression log10 scale, set -5.528. LWbeta point estimate beta length-weight regression log10 scale, set 3.273.
code: # create life history parameter object LH <- makeLH(N0=100,tmax=15,Linf=592,K=0.20,t0=-0.3,LWalpha=-5.528,LWbeta=3.273)

what: Estimate yield for one minimum length limit and variable conditional fishing and conditional natural mortality.
title: Estimate yield based on a single minimum length limit
text: function yprBH_minLL_fixed() function used yield estimated single fixed minimum length limit. function requires minimum length minLL; specified range conditional fishing mortality setting minimum cfmin, maximum cfmax, increment cfinc; specified range conditional natural mortality setting minimum cmmin, maximum cmmax, increment cminc; set length interest monitor loi; life history parameters lhparams. rFAMS includes function est_natmort() estimate instantaneous natural mortality (M) conditional natural mortality (cm) using parameters specified life history parameter object. See FSA package methods calculating M cm. generate range average M cm using rFAMS: decided range cf cm decided minimum length limit consider, can now proceed estimating yield. following example uses life history object created minimum length limit 200mm, cf 0.1 0.9 increments 0.1, cm 0.1 0.9 increments 0.1, monitors lengths 200, 250, 300, 350mm. output object data.frame following calculated values: yield estimated yield (g). exploitation exploitation rate. nharvest number harvested fish. ndie number fish die natural deaths. nt number fish time tr (time become harvestable size). avgwt average weight fish harvested. avglen average length fish harvested. tr time fish recruit minimum length limit (.e., time enter fishery). F instantaneous rate fishing mortality. M instantaneous rate natural mortality. Z instantaneous rate total mortality. S (total) annual rate survival. Natxxx number reach length interest supplied. one column length interest. convenience data.frame also contains model input values (minLL; cf derived cfmin, cfmax, cfinc; cm derived cmmin, cmmax, cminc; N0; Linf; K; t0; LWalpha; LWbeta; tmax). View first rows output

title: Estimate yield based on a single minimum length limit
text: now create series figures aid interpreting output. First, custom theme created use across plots. first figure yield curve displays relationship yield function exploitation specified conditional natural morality cm. example uses cm = 0.30, close estimated mean cm 0.27.  next figure demonstrates explore number fish reaching specified length. figure creates plot showing number fish reaching 300mm function exploitation. Note based conditional natural mortality cm 0.30 filtered code block .  last example figure plots number fish reaching lengths interests monitored function exploitation conditional natural mortality cm 0.30 filtered .
code: # Custom theme for plots (to make look nice) theme_FAMS <- function(...) {  theme_bw() +  theme(    panel.grid.major=element_blank(),panel.grid.minor=element_blank(),    axis.text=element_text(size=14,color="black"),    axis.title=element_text(size=16,color="black"),    axis.title.y=element_text(angle=90),    axis.line=element_line(color="black"),    panel.border=element_blank()  ) } # Round cm to account for "floating point arithmetic inaccuracies" # will be fixed in next version of rFAMS so this isn't needed Res_1$cm <- round(Res_1$cm,8)  # Extract results for cm=0.30 plot_dat <- Res_1 |> dplyr::filter(cm==0.30)  ggplot(data=plot_dat,mapping=aes(x=exploitation,y=yield)) +  geom_point() +  geom_line() +  labs(y="Yield (g)",x="Exploitation (u)") +  theme_FAMS() ggplot(data=plot_dat,mapping=aes(x=exploitation,y=`nAt300`)) +  geom_point() +  geom_line() +  labs(y="Number of fish at 300 mm",x="Exploitation (u)") +  theme_FAMS() # Select columns for plotting and convert to long plot_data_long <- plot_dat %>%  select(exploitation,`nAt200`, `nAt250`, `nAt300`, `nAt350`) %>%  pivot_longer(!exploitation, names_to="loi",values_to="number")  # Generate plot ggplot(data=plot_data_long,mapping=aes(x=exploitation,y=number,group=loi,color=loi)) +  geom_point() +  scale_color_discrete(name="Yield",labels=c("N at 200 mm", "N at 250 mm", "N at 300 mm", "N at 350 mm"))+  geom_line() +  labs(y="Number of fish",x="Exploitation (u)") +  theme_FAMS() +  theme(legend.position = "top")+  guides(color=guide_legend(title="Length of interest"))

title: Estimate yield based on a slot limit
text: now create series figures aid interpreting output. First, custom theme created use across plots. first figure yield curve displays relationship yield function conditional natural mortality.  next figure demonstrates explore number fish reaching specified length. figure creates plot showing number fish reaching 350mm function conditional natural mortality.  last example figure plots yield function conditional natural mortality across three size classes; slot limit, within slot limit, slot limit.
code: # Custom theme for plots (to make look nice) theme_FAMS <- function(...) {  theme_bw() +  theme(    panel.grid.major=element_blank(),panel.grid.minor=element_blank(),    axis.text=element_text(size=14,color="black"),    axis.title=element_text(size=16,color="black"),    axis.title.y=element_text(angle=90),    axis.line=element_line(color="black"),    panel.border=element_blank()  ) } # Total Yield vs Conditional Natural Mortality (cm) ggplot(data=Res_1,mapping=aes(x=cm,y=yieldTotal)) +   geom_point() +   geom_line() +   labs(y="Total yield (g)",x="Conditional natural mortality (cm)") +   theme_FAMS() #Plot number of fish reaching 350 mm as a function of cm ggplot(data=Res_1,mapping=aes(x=cm ,y=`nAt350`)) +   geom_point() +   geom_line() +   labs(y="Number of fish at 450 mm",x="Conditional natural mortality (cm )") +   theme_FAMS() # Yield under, in, and above the slot limit vs Conditional Natural Mortality (cm) # Select columns for plotting plot_data <- Res_1 %>%   select(cm, yieldUnder, yieldIn, yieldAbove) %>%   pivot_longer(!cm, names_to="YieldCat",values_to="Yield")  # Generate plot ggplot(data=plot_data,mapping=aes(x=cm,y=Yield,group=YieldCat,color=YieldCat)) +   geom_point() +   scale_color_discrete(name="Yield",labels=c("Above SL","Within SL","Under SL"))+   geom_line() +   labs(y="Total yield (g)",x="Conditional natural mortality (cm)") +   theme_FAMS() +   theme(legend.position = "top")+   guides(color=guide_legend(title="Slot limit"))

what: Build a life history parameter list
title: Estimate yield based on multiple minimum length limits
text: first step using rFAMS simulation models create object life history parameters using makeLH() function. makeLH() function creates list life history parameters needed. Including, initial number recruits, maximum age fish population, von Bertalanffy growth model parameters (L∞L_\infty, KK, t0t_0), parameters log10-transformed weight length model (alpha beta). default, makeLH() returns list. Growth length-weight model paramaters can generated functions FSA package. example uses following life history parameters: - initial number recruits, set 100. - tmax maximum age population years, set 15. - Linf point estimate asymptotic mean length von Bertalanffy growth model, set 592mm. - K (upper case) point estimate Brody growth coefficient von Bertalanffy growth model, set 0.20. - t0 point estimate x-intercept (.e., theoretical age mean length 0) von Bertalanffy growth model, set -0.3. - LWalpha point estimate alpha length-weight regression log10 scale, set -5.528. - LWbeta point estimate beta length-weight regression log10 scale, set 3.273.
code: # create life history parameter object LH <- makeLH(N0=100,tmax=15,Linf=592,K=0.20,t0=-0.3,LWalpha=-5.528,LWbeta=3.273)

what: Estimate yield for multiple minimum length limit and multiple conditional fishing and conditional natural mortality.
title: Estimate yield based on multiple minimum length limits
text: function yprBH_minLL_var() function used yield estimated single fixed minimum length limit. function requires minimum length minLL; specified range conditional fishing mortality setting minimum cfmin, maximum cfmax, increment cfinc; specified range conditional natural mortality setting minimum cmmin, maximum cmmax, increment cminc; set length interest monitor loi; life history parameters lhparams. rFAMS includes function est_natmort() estimate instantaneous natural mortality (M) conditional natural mortality (cm) using parameters specified life history parameter object. See FSA package methods calculating M cm. generate range average M cm using rFAMS: decided range cf cm decided minimum length limit consider, can now proceed estimating yield. following example uses life history object created minimum length limit 200mm, cf 0.1 0.9 increments 0.1, cm 0.1 0.9 increments 0.1, monitors lengths 200, 250, 300, 350mm. output object data.frame following calculated values: yield estimated yield (g). exploitation exploitation rate. nharvest number harvested fish. ndie number fish die natural deaths. nt number fish time tr (time become harvestable size). avgwt average weight fish harvested. avglen average length fish harvested. tr time fish recruit minimum length limit (.e., time enter fishery). F instantaneous rate fishing mortality. M instantaneous rate natural mortality. Z instantaneous rate total mortality. S (total) annual rate survival. nAtxxx number reach length interest supplied. one column length interest. convenience data.frame also contains model input values (minLL derived lengthmin, lengthmax, lengthinc; cf derived cfmin, cfmax, cfinc; cm derived cmmin, cmmax, cminc; N0; Linf; K; t0; LWalpha; LWbeta; tmax). View first rows output

title: Estimate yield based on multiple minimum length limits
text: now create series figures aid interpreting output. First, custom theme created use across plots. first graph yield curve displays relationship yield function exploitation specified conditional natural morality cm. example uses cm = 0.30, close estimated mean cm 0.27  next graph plots yield curves function exploitation multiple minimum lengths specified conditional natural morality cm. example uses cm = 0.30, .  next graph demonstrates explore number fish reaching specified length. figure creates plot showing number fish reaching 450mm function exploitation. Note based conditional natural mortality cm 0.30 filtered code block .  next example graph plots number fish reaching lengths interests monitored function exploitation conditional natural mortality cm 0.30 filtered .  final two graphs demonstrate construct isopleths using ggplot2 metR packages. use data filtered conditional natural mortality cm 0.30.
code: # Custom theme for plots (to make look nice) theme_FAMS <- function(...) {  theme_bw() +  theme(    panel.grid.major=element_blank(),panel.grid.minor=element_blank(),    axis.text=element_text(size=14,color="black"),    axis.title=element_text(size=16,color="black"),    axis.title.y=element_text(angle=90),    axis.line=element_line(color="black"),    panel.border=element_blank()  ) } # Round cm to account for "floating point arithmetic inaccuracies" # will be fixed in next version of rFAMS so this isn't needed Res_1$cm <- round(Res_1$cm,8)  # Extract results for cm=0.40 and minimum length limit=400 plot_dat <- Res_1 |> dplyr::filter(cm==0.30,minLL==400)  ggplot(data=plot_dat,mapping=aes(x=exploitation,y=yield)) +   geom_point() +   geom_line() +   labs(y="Total yield (g)",x="Exploitation (u)") +   theme_FAMS() # Round cm to account for "floating point arithmetic inaccuracies" # will be fixed in next version of rFAMS so this isn't needed Res_1$cm <- round(Res_1$cm,8)  # Extract results for cm=0.40 and minimum length limit=400 plot_dat <- Res_1 |> dplyr::filter(cm==0.30)  ggplot(data=plot_dat,mapping=aes(y=yield,x=exploitation,group=minLL,color=minLL)) +   geom_line(linewidth=1) +   scale_color_gradient2(high="black") +   labs(y="Total yield (g)",x="Exploitation (u)",color="Min Length Limit") +   theme_FAMS() # Extract results for cm=0.40 and minimum length limit=400 plot_dat <- Res_1 |> dplyr::filter(cm==0.30,minLL==400)  ggplot(data=plot_dat,mapping=aes(x=exploitation,y=`nAt450`)) +   geom_point() +   geom_line() +   labs(y="Number of fish at 450 mm",x="Exploitation (u)") +   theme_FAMS() # Select columns for plotting and convert to long plot_data_long <- plot_dat %>%  select(exploitation,`nAt400`, `nAt450`, `nAt500`, `nAt550`) %>%  pivot_longer(!exploitation, names_to="loi",values_to="number")  # Generate plot ggplot(data=plot_data_long,mapping=aes(x=exploitation,y=number,group=loi,color=loi)) +  geom_point() +  scale_color_discrete(name="Yield",labels=c("N at 400 mm", "N at 450 mm", "N at 500 mm", "N at 550 mm"))+  geom_line() +  labs(y="Number of fish",x="Exploitation (u)") +  theme_FAMS() +  theme(legend.position = "top")+  guides(color=guide_legend(title="Length of interest")) # Extract results for cm=0.40 and minimum length limit=400 plot_dat <- Res_1 |> dplyr::filter(cm==0.30)  # Yield isopleths for varying minLL and exploitation with cm=0.40 # Using same data as previous example ggplot(data=plot_dat,mapping=aes(x=exploitation,y=minLL,z=yield)) +   geom_contour2(aes(label = after_stat(level))) +   xlab("Exploitation (u)") +   ylab("Minimum length limit (mm)") +   theme_FAMS() # Same isopleth as previous but using number harvested instead of yield ggplot(data=plot_dat,mapping=aes(x=exploitation,y=minLL,z=nharvest)) +   geom_contour2(aes(label = after_stat(level))) +   xlab("Exploitation (u)")+   ylab("Minimum length limit (mm)")+   theme_FAMS()

what: Fisheries Analysis and Modeling Simulator in R
title: Fisheries Analysis and Modeling Simulator
text: Simulates dynamics exploited fish populations using Jones modification Beverton-Holt equilibrium yield equation compute yield-per-recruit dynamic pool models (Ricker 1975) https://publications.gc.ca/site/eng/480738/publication.html. Allows users evaluate minimum, slot, inverted length limits exploited fisheries using specified life history parameters. Users can simulate population variety conditional fishing mortality conditional natural mortality. Calculated quantities include number fish harvested dying naturally, mean weight length fish harvested, number fish reach specified lengths interest, total number fish biomass population, stock density indices. package maintained Jason Doll, Associate Professor Fisheries Francis Marion University

text: Estimate yield using Beverton-Holt Yield-per-Recruit (YPR) model using ranges values conditional fishing mortality (cf), conditional natural mortality (cm), minimum length limits harvest (minLL).

title: Main function to simulate expected yield using the Dynamic Pool model for a range of input parameters, including minimum length limits for harvest — dpmBH
code: dpmBH(   simyears,   minLL,   cf,   cm,   rec,   lhparms,   matchRicker = FALSE,   species = NULL,   group = NULL )

title: Main function to simulate expected yield using the Dynamic Pool model for a range of input parameters, including minimum length limits for harvest — dpmBH
text: simyears single numeric lower limit minimum length limit harvest mm. minLL single numeric representing minimum length limit harvest mm. cf matrix conditional fishing mortality row represents year column represents age. Ages age-0 maximum age. cm matrix conditional natural mortality row represents year column represents age. Ages age-0 maximum age. rec numeric vector length simyears specify recruitment year. vector can geneated using genRecruits() function. lhparms named vector list contains values N0, tmax, Linf, K, t0, LWalpha, LWbeta. See makeLH definitions life history parameters. Also see details. matchRicker logical indicates whether yield function match Ricker (). Defaults TRUE. reason changed FALSE try match output FAMS. See "YPR_FAMSvRICKER" article. species single character specify species used simulation define length stock, quality, preferred, memorable, trophy. Length categories obtained FSA package, see PSDlit documentation. group single character specify sub-group name species used simulation define length stock, quality, preferred, memorable, trophy. Length categories obtained FSA package, see PSDlit documentation.

title: Main function to simulate expected yield using the Dynamic Pool model for a range of input parameters, including minimum length limits for harvest — dpmBH
text: list two data.frame object. first list item contains data.frame following calculated values summary age: year year number simulation ycis year class number simulation age age fish year class length length age beginning year based parameters supplied von Bertlanffy growth model. weight total weight beginning year length age based parameters supplied weight-length model. N_start number fish alive start year given age year class. explitation exploitation rate age based supplied conditional fishing mortality rate. expect_nat_death expectation natural death based supplied conditional natural mortality rate. cf supplied conditional fishing mortality rate. cm supplied conditional natural mortality rate. F instantaneous rate fishing mortality. M instantaneous rate natural mortality. Z instantaneous rate total mortality. S (total) annual rate survival. biomass total biomass fish age year N_harvest total number fish harvested age year N_die total number fish die age year yield estimated yield (g). minLL minimum length limit specified simulation N0 number initial convenience data.frame also contains model input values (minLL, N0, N0, Linf, K, t0, LWalpha, LWbeta, tmax). data.frame also contains notes value may contain abbreviations "issues" occurred computing results adjusted . possible abbreviates follows: minLL>=Linf: minimum length limit (minLL) explored greater given asymptotic mean length (Linf). purpose () computing time recruitment fishery (tr) Linf set minLL+0.1. tr<t0: age recruitment fishery (tr) less hypothetical time mean length zero (t0). fish recruit fishery prior length 0 tr set t0. also assures time takes recruit fishery greater 0. Y=Infinite: calculated yield (Y) infinity, impossible suggests propblem. Yield set NA. Y<0: calculated yield (Y) negative, impossible. Yield set 0. Nharv<0: calculated number fish harvested (Nharv) negative, possible. Number harvested set 0. Ndie<0: calculated number fish recruiting fishery died naturally (Ndie) negative, possible. Number died set 0. agvglen<minLL: average length harvested fish less given minimum length limit explored, possible (legal harvest). average length set minimum length limit. second list item contains data.frame following calculated values summary year: year year number simulation substock number substock sized fish age year beginning year. stock number stock sized fish age year beginning year. quality number quality sized fish age year beginning year. preferred number preferred sized fish age year beginning year. memorable number memorable sized fish age year beginning year. trophy number trophy sized fish age year beginning year. PSD number quality sized fish divided number stock sized multiplied 100. PSD_P number preferred sized fish divided number stock sized multiplied 100. PSD_M number memorable sized fish divided number stock sized multiplied 100. PSD_T number trophy sized fish divided number stock sized multiplied 100. Age_1plus total number fish age-1 plus per year. Yield_Age_1plus total year age-1 plus fish per year. Total_biomass total biomass age-1 plus fish per year. N_harvest_Age_1plus number age-1 plus fish harvested per year. N_die_Age_1plus nubmer age-1 plus fish die per year. PSD-X calculated based number fish category (stock, quality, preferred, memorable, trophy) beginning year. , length age start year used assign PSD-X categories age. example, Quality size 300mm, age-1 fish 275mm start year counted quality sized fish, age-2 fish 325mm start year counted quality sized fish.

title: Main function to simulate expected yield using the Dynamic Pool model for a range of input parameters, including minimum length limits for harvest — dpmBH
text: Details

title: Main function to simulate expected yield using the Dynamic Pool model for a range of input parameters, including minimum length limits for harvest — dpmBH
text: Jason C. Doll, jason.doll@fmarion.edu

title: Main function to simulate expected yield using the Dynamic Pool model for a range of input parameters, including minimum length limits for harvest — dpmBH
code: #load required library library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: 'dplyr' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union library(ggplot2)  # Example of simulating yield with the dynamic pool model,  lhparms <- makeLH(N0=100,tmax=30,Linf=1349.5,K=0.111,t0=0.065,             LWalpha=-5.2147,LWbeta=3.153) simyears <- 50 minLL <- 400 rec <- genRecruits(method = "fixed", nR = 100, simyears = simyears) cm <- matrix(rep(c(rep(0,1), rep(0.18,(lhparms$tmax))), simyears),nrow=simyears,byrow=TRUE) cf <- matrix(rep(c(rep(0,1), rep(0.33,(lhparms$tmax))), simyears),nrow=simyears,byrow=TRUE)  out<-dpmBH(simyears = simyears, minLL = minLL, cf = cf, cm = cm, rec = rec, lhparms = lhparms,            matchRicker=FALSE,species="Striped Bass",group="landlocked")  #Use summary by year data frame to plot yield vs year ggplot(data=out[[2]],mapping=aes(x=year,y=Yield_age_1plus)) +   geom_point() +   geom_line() +   labs(y="Total yield (g)",x="Year") +   theme_bw()   #Plot date using summary by age #filter for year class = 1 plotdat<- out[[1]] |> filter(yc==1) #Plot yield vs age ggplot(data=plotdat,mapping=aes(x=age,y=yield)) +   geom_point() +   geom_line() +   labs(y="Total yield (g)",x="Age") +   theme_bw()   #Recruitment based on a normal distribution rec <- genRecruits(method = "normal", simyears = simyears,                    meanR = 1000, sdR = 500, minR = 100, maxR =2500) cm <- matrix(rep(c(rep(0,1), rep(0.18,(lhparms$tmax))), simyears),nrow=simyears,byrow=TRUE) cf <- matrix(rep(c(rep(0,1), rep(0.33,(lhparms$tmax))), simyears),nrow=simyears,byrow=TRUE)  out_2<-dpmBH(simyears = simyears, minLL = minLL, cf = cf, cm = cm, rec = rec, lhparms = lhparms,              matchRicker=FALSE,species="Striped Bass",group="landlocked")  #Use summary by year data frame to plot yield vs year ggplot(data=out_2[[2]],mapping=aes(x=year,y=PSD)) +   geom_point() +   geom_line() +   labs(y="PSD",x="Year") +   theme_bw()   #Plot date using summary by age #Plot yield vs age for each year class ggplot(data=out_2[[1]],mapping=aes(x=age,y=yield,group=yc,color=yc)) +   geom_point() +   geom_line() +   labs(y="Total yield (g)",x="Age") +   theme_bw()

what: Simulate yield using the dynamic pool model. — dpmBH_func
title: Simulate yield using the dynamic pool model. — dpmBH_func
text: Estimate yield--age using Beverton-Holt Yield-per-Recruit (YPR) model single year-class. main function accepts  minimum length limit harvest (minLL), vector conditional fishing mortality (cf), vector conditional natural mortality (cm), vector recruitment abundance (rec), life history parameters (lhparams).

title: Simulate yield using the dynamic pool model. — dpmBH_func
code: dpmBH_func(minLL, cf, cm, rec, lhparms, matchRicker = FALSE)

title: Simulate yield using the dynamic pool model. — dpmBH_func
text: minLL single numeric representing minimum length limit harvest mm. cf matrix conditional fishing mortality row represents year column represents age. Ages age-0 maximum age. cm matrix conditional natural mortality row represents year column represents age. Ages age-0 maximum age. rec single numeric representing number recruits. lhparms named vector list contains values N0, tmax, Linf, K, t0, LWalpha, LWbeta. See makeLH definitions life history parameters. Also see details. matchRicker logical indicates whether yield function match Ricker (). Defaults TRUE. reason changed FALSE try match output FAMS. See "YPR_FAMSvRICKER" article.

title: Simulate yield using the dynamic pool model. — dpmBH_func

M instantaneous rate natural mortality. Z instantaneous rate total mortality. S (total) annual rate survival tr time fish recruit minimum length limit (.e., time enter fishery). text: Jason C. Doll, jason.doll@fmarion.edu

title: Main function to simulate expected yield using the Dynamic Pool model for a range of input parameters, including minimum length limits for harvest — dpmBH_MinLL_fixed
code: #load required library library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: 'dplyr' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union library(ggplot2)  # Example of simulating yield with the dynamic pool model,  lhparms <- makeLH(N0=100,tmax=30,Linf=1349.5,K=0.111,t0=0.065,             LWalpha=-5.2147,LWbeta=3.153) simyears <- 50 minLL <- 400 rec <- genRecruits(method = "fixed", nR = 100, simyears = simyears) cm <- matrix(rep(c(rep(0,1), rep(0.18,(lhparms$tmax))), simyears),nrow=simyears,byrow=TRUE) cf <- matrix(rep(c(rep(0,1), rep(0.33,(lhparms$tmax))), simyears),nrow=simyears,byrow=TRUE)  out<-dpmBH_MinLL_fixed(simyears = simyears, minLL = minLL, cf = cf,                        cm = cm, rec = rec, lhparms = lhparms,                        matchRicker=FALSE,species="Striped Bass",group="landlocked")  #Use summary by year data frame to plot yield vs year ggplot(data=out[[2]],mapping=aes(x=year,y=Yield_age_1plus)) +   geom_point() +   geom_line() +   labs(y="Total yield (g)",x="Year") +   theme_bw()   #Plot date using summary by age #filter for year class = 1 plotdat<- out[[1]] |> filter(yc==1) #Plot yield vs age ggplot(data=plotdat,mapping=aes(x=age,y=yield)) +   geom_point() +   geom_line() +   labs(y="Total yield (g)",x="Age") +   theme_bw()   #Recruitment based on a normal distribution rec <- genRecruits(method = "normal", simyears = simyears,                    meanR = 1000, sdR = 500, minR = 100, maxR =2500) cm <- matrix(rep(c(rep(0,1), rep(0.18,(lhparms$tmax))), simyears),nrow=simyears,byrow=TRUE) cf <- matrix(rep(c(rep(0,1), rep(0.33,(lhparms$tmax))), simyears),nrow=simyears,byrow=TRUE)  out_2<-dpmBH_MinLL_fixed(simyears = simyears, minLL = minLL, cf = cf,                          cm = cm, rec = rec, lhparms = lhparms,                          matchRicker=FALSE,species="Striped Bass",group="landlocked")  #Use summary by year data frame to plot yield vs year ggplot(data=out_2[[2]],mapping=aes(x=year,y=PSD)) +   geom_point() +   geom_line() +   labs(y="PSD",x="Year") +   theme_bw()   #Plot date using summary by age #Plot yield vs age for each year class ggplot(data=out_2[[1]],mapping=aes(x=age,y=yield,group=yc,color=yc)) +   geom_point() +   geom_line() +   labs(y="Total yield (g)",x="Age") +   theme_bw()

code: # An example lhparm as would be returned from makeLH tmp <- list(N0=100,tmax=15,Linf=500,K=0.3,t0=-0.5,LWalpha=-5.16,LWbeta=3.1)  # All methods in metaM() that use those life history parameters est_natmort(tmp) #>            method          M         cm                  givens #> 1       HoenigNLS 0.41002265 0.33636478                 tmax=15 #> 2         HoenigO 0.29543534 0.25579246                 tmax=15 #> 3        HoenigO2 0.29631969 0.25645032                 tmax=15 #> 4        HoenigLM 0.36126963 0.30320890                 tmax=15 #> 5    HewittHoenig 0.28133333 0.24522330                 tmax=15 #> 6           tmax1 0.34060000 0.28865661                 tmax=15 #> 7       PaulyLNoT 0.47024562 0.37515122          K=0.3, Linf=50 #> 8              K1 0.50760000 0.39806150                   K=0.3 #> 9              K2 0.56300000 0.43050200                   K=0.3 #> 10      HamelCope 0.36000000 0.30232367                 tmax=15 #> 11       JensenK1 0.45000000 0.36237185                   K=0.3 #> 12       JensenK2 0.65100000 0.47847601                   K=0.3 #> 13 AlversonCarney 0.19872105 0.18022146          tmax=15, K=0.3 #> 14   ChenWatanabe 0.07181977 0.06930138 tmax=15, K=0.3, t0=-0.5  # Same but including the average in the last row est_natmort(tmp,incl.avg=TRUE) #>            method          M         cm                  givens #> 1       HoenigNLS 0.41002265 0.33636478                 tmax=15 #> 2         HoenigO 0.29543534 0.25579246                 tmax=15 #> 3        HoenigO2 0.29631969 0.25645032                 tmax=15 #> 4        HoenigLM 0.36126963 0.30320890                 tmax=15 #> 5    HewittHoenig 0.28133333 0.24522330                 tmax=15 #> 6           tmax1 0.34060000 0.28865661                 tmax=15 #> 7       PaulyLNoT 0.47024562 0.37515122          K=0.3, Linf=50 #> 8              K1 0.50760000 0.39806150                   K=0.3 #> 9              K2 0.56300000 0.43050200                   K=0.3 #> 10      HamelCope 0.36000000 0.30232367                 tmax=15 #> 11       JensenK1 0.45000000 0.36237185                   K=0.3 #> 12       JensenK2 0.65100000 0.47847601                   K=0.3 #> 13 AlversonCarney 0.19872105 0.18022146          tmax=15, K=0.3 #> 14   ChenWatanabe 0.07181977 0.06930138 tmax=15, K=0.3, t0=-0.5 #> 15        AVERAGE 0.37552622 0.30586468                          # Selecting just one method est_natmort(tmp,method="HoenigNLS") #>      method         M        cm  givens #> 1 HoenigNLS 0.4100226 0.3363648 tmax=15  # Selecting several methods est_natmort(tmp,method=c("HoenigNLS","HoenigO","HoenigO2","HoenigLM")) #>      method         M        cm  givens #> 1 HoenigNLS 0.4100226 0.3363648 tmax=15 #> 2   HoenigO 0.2954353 0.2557925 tmax=15 #> 3  HoenigO2 0.2963197 0.2564503 tmax=15 #> 4  HoenigLM 0.3612696 0.3032089 tmax=15  # A method that uses a parameter not usually in lhparms est_natmort(tmp,method="QuinnDeriso",PS=0.05) #>        method         M        cm           givens #> 1 QuinnDeriso 0.1997155 0.1810363 PS=0.05, tmax=15  # Selecting all Hoenig methods using Mmethods from FSA est_natmort(tmp,method=FSA::Mmethods("Hoenig")) #>          method         M        cm  givens #> 1     HoenigNLS 0.4100226 0.3363648 tmax=15 #> 2       HoenigO 0.2954353 0.2557925 tmax=15 #> 3      HoenigOF 0.2793944 0.2437585 tmax=15 #> 4      HoenigOM 0.3594796 0.3019605 tmax=15 #> 5      HoenigOC 0.2409592 0.2141263 tmax=15 #> 6      HoenigO2 0.2963197 0.2564503 tmax=15 #> 7     HoenigO2F 0.2568301 0.2265003 tmax=15 #> 8     HoenigO2M 0.3521442 0.2968213 tmax=15 #> 9     HoenigO2C 0.3110774 0.2673428 tmax=15 #> 10     HoenigLM 0.3612696 0.3032089 tmax=15 #> 11 HewittHoenig 0.2813333 0.2452233 tmax=15  # Over-riding the Linf param in parameters list, but others from tmp est_natmort(tmp,method="PaulyLNoT")              # Linf from tmp #>      method         M        cm         givens #> 1 PaulyLNoT 0.4702456 0.3751512 K=0.3, Linf=50 est_natmort(tmp,Linf=1000/10,method="PaulyLNoT") # Linf from Linf= arg #>      method         M        cm          givens #> 1 PaulyLNoT 0.3740975 0.3120902 K=0.3, Linf=100

what: Make a list or vector of life history parameters for yield-per-recruit analyses. — makeLH
title: Make a list or vector of life history parameters for yield-per-recruit analyses. — makeLH
text: Efficiently construct either vector list contains seven life history parameters required Beverton-Holt yield-per-recruit analyses. parameters can given user function arguments. Alternativvely, von Bertalanffy parameters (Linf, K, t0) may extracted nls object created fitting von Bertalanffy equation length--age data (object created outside function). Similarly log10-transformed weight-length model coefficients may extracted lm object created fitting model transformed weight-length data (object created outside function). parameter values checked sanity (e.g., Linf>0).

title: Make a list or vector of life history parameters for yield-per-recruit analyses. — makeLH
text: N0 single numeric represents number fish population hypothetical age t0. tmax single whole number represents maximum age population years. Linf single numeric represents point estimate asymptotic mean length von Bertalanffy growth model nls object created fitting von Bertalanffy equation length--age data. K single numeric represents point estimate Brody growth coefficient von Bertalanffy growth model. t0 single numeric represents point estimate x-intercept (.e., theoretical age mean length 0) von Bertalanffy growth model. LWalpha single numeric represents point estimate alpha length-weight regression log10 scale lm object created fitting model log10-transformed weight-length data. LWbeta single numeric represents point estimate beta length-weight regression log10 scale. restype character indicates type output (list vector) returned function.

code: # Best practice for entering life history parameter values LH <- makeLH(N0=100,tmax=15,Linf=600,K=0.30,t0=-0.6,              LWalpha=-5.453,LWbeta=3.10)  # Works but no checks on the values LH <- list(N0=100,tmax=15,Linf=600,K=0.30,t0=-0.6,            LWalpha=-5.453,LWbeta=3.10)

title: Make a list or vector of life history parameters for yield-per-recruit analyses. — makeLH
code: library(FSA) #> ## FSA v0.10.1. See citation('FSA') if used in publication. #> ## Run fishR() for related website and fishR('IFAR') for related book. library(FSAdata) #> ## FSAdata v0.4.1. See ?FSAdata to find data for specific fisheries analyses. library(dplyr)  # ----- Simple examples with explicity arguments for each ------------------- makeLH(N0=100,tmax=15,Linf=500,K=0.3,t0=-0.5,LWalpha=-5.613,LWbeta=3.1) #> $N0 #> [1] 100 #>  #> $tmax #> [1] 15 #>  #> $Linf #> [1] 500 #>  #> $K #> [1] 0.3 #>  #> $t0 #> [1] -0.5 #>  #> $LWalpha #> [1] -5.613 #>  #> $LWbeta #> [1] 3.1 #>  makeLH(N0=100,tmax=15,Linf=500,K=0.3,t0=-0.5,LWalpha=-5.613,LWbeta=3.1,        restype="vector") #>      N0    tmax    Linf       K      t0 LWalpha  LWbeta  #> 100.000  15.000 500.000   0.300  -0.500  -5.613   3.100   # ----- Example of extracting values from model fits ------------------------ # N0 and tmax provided as arguments ... Linf, K, and t0 extracted from nls #   output and LWalpha and LWbeta extracted from lm output. Note that nls #   and lm output here are just examples of the function, they should be #   calculated for the same species from the same waterbody, etc.  # Load data from FSAdata package, restrict to one location and year, # create log10 values of weight and length data(WalleyeErie2,package="FSAdata") tmp <- WalleyeErie2 |>   filter(loc==2,year==2010) |>   mutate(logW=log10(w),          logL=log10(tl))  # Generate LVB results vb1 <- FSA::makeGrowthFun(type="von Bertalanffy") fit1 <- nls(tl~vb1(age,Linf,K,t0),data=tmp,             start=FSA::findGrowthStarts(tl~age,data=tmp))  # Generate length-weight regression results fit2 <- lm(logW~logL,data=tmp)  # Make life-history list with those results waeLH <- makeLH(N0=100,tmax=15,Linf=fit1,LWalpha=fit2) waeLH #> $N0 #> [1] 100 #>  #> $tmax #> [1] 15 #>  #> $Linf #> [1] 587.9484 #>  #> $K #> [1] 0.4851255 #>  #> $t0 #> [1] -1.050782 #>  #> $LWalpha #> [1] -5.857295 #>  #> $LWbeta #> [1] 3.329038 #>

title: Main function to simulate expected yield using the Beverton-Holt Yield-per-Recruit model for a range of input parameters — yprBH_minLL_fixed
code: # Load other required packages for organizing output and plotting library(dplyr)    ## for filter library(ggplot2)  ## for ggplot et al.  # Life history parameters to be used below LH <- makeLH(N0=100,tmax=15,Linf=592,K=0.20,t0=-0.3,LWalpha=-5.528,LWbeta=3.273)  # Estimate yield for multiple values of minLL, cf, and cm # # This is a minimal example, lengthinc, cfinc, cminc would likely be smaller # #   to produce finer-scaled results Res_1 <- yprBH_minLL_fixed(minLL=200,                          cfmin=0.1,cfmax=0.9,cfinc=0.1,                          cmmin=0.1,cmmax=0.9,cminc=0.1,                          loi=c(200,250,300,350),lhparms=LH)   # Yield curve (yield vs exploitation) # Extract results for cm=0.40 plot_dat <- Res_1 |> dplyr::filter(cm==0.40)  ggplot(data=plot_dat,mapping=aes(x=exploitation,y=yield)) +   geom_point() +   geom_line() +   labs(y="Yield (g)",x="Exploitation (u)") +   theme_bw()   # Plot number of fish reaching 300 mm as a function of exploitation with cm = 0.40 ggplot(data=plot_dat,mapping=aes(x=exploitation,y=`nAt300`)) +   geom_point() +   geom_line() +   labs(y="Number of fish at 300 mm",x="Exploitation (u)") +   theme_bw()

title: Main function to simulate expected yield using the Beverton-Holt Yield-per-Recruit model for a range of input parameters, including minimum length limits for harvest — yprBH_minLL_var
code: # Load other required packages for organizing output and plotting library(dplyr)    ## for filter library(ggplot2)  ## for ggplot et al. library(metR)     ## geom_text_contour  # Life history parameters to be used below LH <- makeLH(N0=100,tmax=15,Linf=592,K=0.20,t0=-0.3,LWalpha=-5.528,LWbeta=3.273)  # Estimate yield for multiple values of minLL, cf, and cm # # This is a minimal example, lengthinc, cfinc, cminc would likely be smaller # #   to produce finer-scaled results. Res_1 <- yprBH_minLL_var(lengthmin=200,lengthinc=50,lengthmax=550,                        cfmin=0.1,cfmax=0.9,cfinc=0.1,                        cmmin=0.1,cmmax=0.9,cminc=0.1,                        loi=c(400,450,500,550),lhparms=LH)  # Yield curves (yield vs exploitation) by varying minimum lengths, # using cm=40 plot_dat <- Res_1 |> filter(cm==0.40)  ggplot(data=plot_dat,mapping=aes(y=yield,x=exploitation,                                  group=minLL,color=minLL)) +   geom_line(linewidth=1) +   scale_color_gradient2(high="black") +   labs(y="Yield (g)",x="Exploitation (u)",color="Min Length Limit") +   theme_bw()   # Yield isopleths for varying minLL and exploitation with cm=0.40 # # Using same data as previous example ggplot(data=plot_dat,mapping=aes(x=exploitation,y=minLL,z=yield)) +   geom_contour2(aes(label = after_stat(level))) +   xlab("Exploitation (u)") +   ylab("Minimum length limit (mm)") +   theme_bw()
